title: Automatic Speech Recognition Biases in Newcastle English: an Error Analysis
author: Dana Serditova (University of Freiburg), Kevin Tang (Heinrich Heine University Dusseldorf), Jochen Steffens (University of Applied Sciences Dusseldorf), ...
relevance_why: This paper examines biases in Automatic Speech Recognition systems with a focus on regional dialects, providing insights that can be applied to improve ASR models for diverse linguistic backgrounds, relevant to my studies in audio processing.
background: The paper investigates the performance of Automatic Speech Recognition systems on Newcastle English, highlighting errors attributable to regional dialect features.
contribution: This study introduces a two-stage error analysis methodology to tackle ASR biases in regional dialects, achieving a deeper understanding of the linguistic features affecting recognition accuracy.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous research predominantly focused on social biases (racial, age, gender) affecting ASR but did not adequately address regional dialects.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work systematically analyzes dialect-specific features, providing a framework for recognizing regional biases in ASR systems.

key_innovation: The study utilizes a comprehensive error analysis approach to correlate ASR misrecognitions with phonological, lexical, and morphosyntactic features of Newcastle English.
real_world_impact: The findings advocate for enhancing ASR training data with more regional variety, potentially improving ASR technology's applicability across diverse speaker demographics.
limitations: The absence of linguistic feature tagging may lead to misclassification of dialect patterns as errors.

new_terms.Word Error Rate (WER): **Word Error Rate (WER)** is a common metric for evaluating the performance of ASR systems, calculated as the number of errors divided by the total number of words in the reference transcription.
new_terms.morphosyntactic: **Morphosyntactic** refers to the branch of linguistics that studies how morphological and syntactic processes interact in forming a sentence structure.
